G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 239, §8, as this is a landlord‑tenant dispute concerning residential premises located in Boston, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §3 and G.L. c. 239, §8, as this is a landlord‑tenant dispute concerning residential premises located in Boston, Massachusetts.

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains a covenant of quiet enjoyment, express or implied, assuring the tenant’s right to undisturbed use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.support_reasoning: The opinion directly describes the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the tenancy and applies that covenant to residential leases under G.L. c. 186, § 14. While this case focuses on breach through failure to address criminal activity, it clearly treats quiet enjoyment as an inherent protection of the tenant’s right to undisturbed use and enjoyment of the leased premises, consistent with the proposition that such a covenant is part of every residential lease (by statute or implication).
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains a covenant of quiet enjoyment, express or implied, assuring the tenant’s right to undisturbed use and enjoyment of the leased premises.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair ongoing leaks, remediate moisture damage, and address mold constitutes an unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns late-night noise from a bar operated on adjacent premises and whether that noise, which the landlord could control, constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction. It does stand for the broader principle that a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions within their control that substantially interfere with habitability can violate quiet enjoyment, but it does not address leaks, moisture, or mold, nor does it specifically deal with repair obligations related to water intrusion. Thus it is only analogical support, not direct authority, for the specific proposition about leaks and mold.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant is violated when the landlord allows conditions that render the premises substantially unsuitable for the purposes for which they were rented.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that it protects tenants from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. The court cites and adopts the common-law definition that liability arises where the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions is an interruption of the tenant’s rights, i.e., interferences with use and enjoyment serious enough to render the premises unsuitable for the tenancy’s purposes. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant is violated when conditions make the premises substantially unsuitable for their rented purpose.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”}

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: The covenant is violated when the landlord allows conditions that render the premises substantially unsuitable for the purposes for which they were rented.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for violating the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (requiring at least negligent conduct and notice/foreseeability) but does not articulate the substantive test that the covenant is breached when conditions render premises substantially unsuitable for their rented purpose. That “substantially unsuitable” formulation appears in other Massachusetts quiet enjoyment cases (e.g., Simon, Cruz), but this case focuses instead on the landlord’s degree of fault and rejects strict liability via the lead paint statute. Thus it does not itself provide authority for the proposition as phrased.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102, quoting Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942). In Cruz, we observed that the landlord had notice of the defects in the leased premises which it failed to repair, and that it was ‘wholly foreseeable’ that the injury to the tenant would result from this failure to make the repairs.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Persistent water intrusion and mold growth make the premises uninhabitable and are well beyond “minor cosmetic issues.”
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The case concerns loss of heat and hot water as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and the timing of rent abatement; it does not discuss water intrusion, mold, or any distinction between such conditions and “minor cosmetic issues.” While the opinion makes clear that serious sanitary code violations affecting essential services render premises uninhabitable, it cannot be cited as authority specifically about persistent water intrusion or mold growth. Thus it supports the broader habitability principle, but not the particular proposition stated.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The tenant may not excuse her obligation with mere reasonable efforts to pay rent. Nor may the landlord avoid his duty with mere reasonable efforts to provide a habitable dwelling.”

*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 372 Mass. 1.proposition: Persistent water intrusion and mold growth make the premises uninhabitable and are well beyond “minor cosmetic issues.”
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 372 Mass. 1.case_name: International Heating & Air Conditioning Corp. v. Rich Construction Co.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 372 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns timing and scope of claims under a statutory payment bond on a public construction project, not landlord‑tenant habitability standards, water intrusion, or mold. Nothing in the case discusses conditions of residential premises, what constitutes uninhabitable conditions, or the distinction between cosmetic and substantial defects. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition about water intrusion and mold making premises uninhabitable.
*Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 372 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: We are concerned in the present case solely with the timeliness of the filed claim. No question is presented as to the amount to be recovered if the claim was timely filed.

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach under *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (breach found where landlord allowed conditions causing water leakage).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion finds breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and other duties based on numerous serious defects (lack of heat, missing windows, hazardous flooring, infestation, etc.), but it does not discuss water leakage or conditions specifically involving water intrusion. The proposition characterizes Haddad as a case where breach was found for allowing conditions causing water leakage, which is not reflected in the court’s description of the facts or its holdings. Thus, the case does not support that specific water‑leakage proposition.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.”

*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).proposition: Defendant’s refusal to correct the condition violates G.L. c. 186, §14 and entitles Plaintiff to actual and statutory damages, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs, even though Plaintiff proceeds pro se.
*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a tenant may use a violation of the security deposit statute as a defense to possession under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it does not address statutory damages, attorney’s fees, or costs under § 14, nor the effect of a tenant proceeding pro se on fee recovery. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Meikle v. Nurse*, 474 Mass. 207 (2016).relevant_excerpt:
“The security deposit statute is one such law. Indeed, the security deposit statute has no raison d’etre other than to insure fairness to a tenant who pays a sum to the landlord and relies on the landlord’s good faith for the return of the portion to which he or she is entitled at the end of the tenancy.

Our cases involving the security deposit statute demonstrate its importance in the scheme of protections afforded a tenant… Indeed, the security deposit statute provides for treble damages, costs, and attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 15B (7).”

*Yee v. Mass. State Racing Comm\u2019n*,.raw_text: *Yee v. Mass. State Racing Comm’n*, 481 Mass. 901 (2019)
*Yee v. Mass. State Racing Comm\u2019n*,.proposition: The ongoing leak and mold have deprived Plaintiff of the beneficial enjoyment of her home, a harm that Massachusetts courts recognize as precisely what the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The ongoing leak and mold have deprived Plaintiff of the beneficial enjoyment of her home, a harm that Massachusetts courts recognize as precisely what the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion mentions sanitary code violations and a breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not analyze or even reference the common-law or statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. There is no discussion of conditions like leaks or mold depriving the tenant of beneficial enjoyment as a distinct quiet-enjoyment harm; instead, the court treats the problems solely in terms of code violations and habitability/warranty damages. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the claimed quiet-enjoyment proposition.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
"Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs."

"Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability... The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations."

*Lipsitz v. Robbins*, 19 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The ongoing leak and mold have deprived Plaintiff of the beneficial enjoyment of her home, a harm that Massachusetts courts recognize as precisely what the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits.
*Lipsitz v. Robbins*, 19 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Home Indemnity Insurance v. Merchants Distributors, Inc.
*Lipsitz v. Robbins*, 19 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case is an insurance coverage dispute about which workers’ compensation policy (retrospective vs. standard premium) is responsible for a lump-sum settlement, and how an insurer’s contractual right to settle claims in good faith binds the insured. It does not involve residential tenancies, leaks, mold, habitability, or the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that ongoing leak and mold depriving a tenant of beneficial enjoyment of her home violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.100 et seq..proposition: Order Defendant to promptly repair the leak, remediate all water and mold damage, and ensure the premises meet the Massachusetts Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. §410.100 et seq.;
